plausible_answers.text: Vedic Sanskrit and Classical or "Pāṇinian" Sanskrit

qas.question: What two dialects are vastly different?

context: <b5_0>Sanskrit<b5_0/>, as defined by Pāṇini, evolved out of the <a0_0>earlier Vedic<a0_0/> form. The present form of <b10_0>Vedic <b6_0>Sanskrit<b10_0/><b6_0/> can be traced back to as early as the <a1_0>second millennium BCE<a1_0/> (for Rig-vedic). Scholars often distinguish <b7_0><b8_0>Vedic Sanskrit and Classical or <b11_0>"Pāṇinian" Sanskrit<b11_0/><b8_0/><b7_0/> as <a2_0>separate dialects<a2_0/>. Though they are quite similar, they differ in a number of essential points of phonology, vocabulary, grammar and syntax. Vedic Sanskrit is the language of <a3_0>the Vedas<a3_0/>, a large collection of hymns, incantations (Samhitas) and theological and religio-philosophical discussions in the Brahmanas and Upanishads. Modern linguists consider the <b12_0>metrical hymns<b12_0/> of the <a4_0><b13_0>Rigveda Samhita<b13_0/><a4_0/> to be the earliest, composed by many authors over several centuries of oral tradition. The end of the Vedic period is marked by <b9_0>the <b14_0>composition of the Upanishads<b14_0/>,<b9_0/> which form the concluding part of the traditional Vedic corpus; however, the early Sutras are Vedic, too, both in language and content.
